title: HOMEBREW
subtitle: Installation and use of Homebrew
description: How to get the most out of your Mac with Homebrew
content: Homebrew is a package installer for macOS
Why do I need a package installer?

I'm sorry to say this, but Apple's App Store for Mac is, let's put it this way, limited. Often, for specific programs, you may not find them or... Oh, surprise! You may only be able to install them using the Homebrew installer from the program's official page.
Can I get viruses, mess up my computer, slow it down... in short, can it be bad for my Mac?
Absolutely NO, for several reasons...
The package installer is maintained by a large community, which you can check out in the links at the end of its website.

The installer optimizes the installation, meaning it automatically installs the version that matches your Mac. If it‚Äôs an Intel chip, it installs the Intel version; if it's an Apple Silicon chip, it installs the Silicon version, also considering the operating system version you have, like Big Sur, Monterey, Ventura... This is a big advantage because it searches for the correct program and version for you, which, let‚Äôs face it, can be a hassle to find and install manually.
It installs all packages in their own directory, as explained on the main page, so the program's files aren't scattered around any directory.
Its installation and uninstallation are simple, as are the installation and uninstallation of the packages themselves.
Don‚Äôt be scared if you feel uneasy about using the terminal. It‚Äôs easier than it looks, and in the end, you‚Äôll get the hang of it...
So, with all that said, roll up your sleeves, and let‚Äôs get to work!
<hr>
Installing Homebrew
In this video, we will explain:
- How to install Homebrew (Video Start - 4:00), run in the terminal -> /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
- How to see the available commands and help in Homebrew -> brew help

- How to search for a package by name by running in the terminal -> brew search package_name but there's another way via its searcher. My recommendation is that when you want to search or install a program (any program), search for it here first, and if you find it, install it using Homebrew.
- How to install and uninstall cask packages (Video 4:00 - 6:43), run in the terminal -> brew install --cask package_name -> example: brew install cask telegram
- How to install formulae packages, for example, in the video we‚Äôll install Composer (Video 6:43 - 12:06), run in the terminal -> brew install package_name -> example: brew install composer
- How to see the packages you have installed by running -> brew list
- How to update Homebrew's package list -> brew update
- How to update Homebrew and the installed packages -> brew upgrade
- How to uninstall Homebrew (Video 12:06 - End) run in the terminal -> /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/uninstall.sh)"

title: UTM
subtitle: UTM, a new Virtual Machine
description: We will analyze in depth the UTM virtual machine based on QEMU
content: UTM is a Virtual Machine for macOS
What makes UTM special?

To virtualize operating systems on a Mac with an M1 chip, we can only do it with Parallels, which is paid and very expensive, with VMWare, which requires registration, with VirtualBox for ARM which is still in Beta and doesn't work well, and with QEMU, which is very complicated to use.

The UTM Virtual Machine is the graphical version of the QEMU virtual machine. QEMU is an open-source virtual machine that operates via commands, i.e., through the terminal. It‚Äôs a very complete machine for advanced users.
With UTM, it‚Äôs much easier. It‚Äôs free, and you can download it from here. The main page of UTM. If you choose to download it, you will need to update it yourself.
You can also download it through the AppStore. It‚Äôs a one-time purchase, but you‚Äôll receive automatic updates for UTM and help the developers maintain UTM.
What can we virtualize?

With the UTM machine, we can virtualize many operating systems. ARM-based operating systems will work flawlessly, but Intel-based architectures may cause problems, so be careful. Once, during the installation of a very unusual Intel 32-bit OS, my MacBook overheated, and I had to abort the installation.
Which operating systems have I managed to virtualize?
The OSs have ranged from Windows 2.0.3, Windows XP, Windows 10 ARM, Windows 11 ARM, Ubuntu Server ARM, Kali ARM, Debian ARM, Windows Server 2008 R2,...
Is it difficult to use?

No, but if you come from VirtualBox, it might take a little longer to understand how it works. The installations are a bit more complicated, but once you learn, I think you won't want to use anything else.
Well, enough talk, let‚Äôs get to work
Installing UTM
First, download the UTM.dmg file from the main page of UTM or if you want, directly from the link here.

title: Crop 1:1 Images to 16:9 Using FFmpeg, the Great Unknown
subtitle: Easily turn your square images into professional panoramic formats
description: How to crop 1:1 square images to 16:9 format on Mac using FFmpeg, with Homebrew installation instructions in another post.
content: üîß What is FFmpeg?
FFmpeg is a powerful command-line tool for processing video, audio, and images. Although widely used in professional environments, it remains a hidden gem for many casual users.
Learn more on its official website: ffmpeg.org.
üõ†Ô∏è Installing FFmpeg on macOS
If you don't have Homebrew installed yet, check out our guide: Installing Homebrew on Mac.
Once Homebrew is installed, installing FFmpeg is as simple as running:
brew install ffmpeg
You can verify the installation with:
ffmpeg -version
üñºÔ∏è Cropping a 1:1 square image to 16:9 format
Imagine you have a 1024x1024 pixel image (1:1 ratio) and you want to professionally crop it to a panoramic 16:9 format.
The basic command would be:
ffmpeg -i input.jpeg -vf "crop=iw:iw*9/16:0:(ih-iw*9/16)/2" output.jpeg
This command crops the image centered both horizontally and vertically.
üîº Custom vertical adjustment
Want to move the image up or down within the crop?
To move it up by 100 pixels:
ffmpeg -i input.jpeg -vf "crop=iw:iw*9/16:0:100" output.jpeg
To move it down by 150 pixels:
ffmpeg -i input.jpeg -vf "crop=iw:iw*9/16:0:-150" output.jpeg
üìè Understanding the crop filter
The crop filter syntax is:
crop=width:height:x:y

- width: width of the crop
- height: height of the crop
- x: horizontal offset
- y: vertical offset
This lets you easily customize how your image is positioned inside the 16:9 frame.
üéØ Conclusion

With just a few commands, you can transform square images into professional panoramic crops ‚Äî perfect for social media, presentations, banners, or web projects. A simple trick that will save you tons of time!
